alert.note: Alert for Central Interior (Alaska) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Advisory issued May 18 at 12:49PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY FOR AN ICE JAM IN EFFECT UNTIL 1215 PM AKDT SATURDAY... * WHAT...Flooding caused by an ice jam is occurring. * WHERE...Yukon River between Tanana and the Nowitna River. * WHEN...Until 1215 PM AKDT Saturday. * IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas along the Yukon River between Tanana and Nowitna River. Flooding could be worse near the Nowitna River. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1214 PM AKDT, The River Watch Team reports an ice jam on the Yukon River that extends from Horner Hot Springs upriver to the the Boneyard. This 50 mile long ice jam is backing water up as far as the village of Tanana, which is 40 miles miles upstream of the Boneyard. This jam is likely backing water up the Nowitna River, and other rivers and creeks that drain into the Yukon between Tanana and the Nowitna River. At the village of Tanana, water is now moving into low spots causing minor flooding. At Tanana, water is expected to rise very slowly over the next day or two with minor flooding of low spots to continue. Areas closer to the ice jam such as the Nowitna River could see higher flood levels. - Minor flooding in Tanana is expected to continue into the weekend. Water levels may rise very slowly over the next day at Tanana, but flooding is expected to remain in low lying areas. Flooding along the Yukon River downstream closer to the Nowitna River will likely be worse. Flooding on the Nowitna River may occur as well. - For Tanana: At 9:00am the stage was 84.96 feet. Flood Stage is 86.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood - If you live near or along the Yukon River between the Nowitna River and Tanana, or along the lower Nowitna River, stay alert and be prepared to take action.
info.instruction: People along the Yukon River between Tanana and the Nowitna River should prepare for high water. Move valuables away from the river to higher ground.
